text:
A woman has had a 70-pound cyst removed after it began crushing her lungs and put her at risk of heart failure.
The cyst is thought to be the biggest to have ever been removed whole.
The 24-year-old woman, from Mexico, who did not want to be named, noticed she had put on more than 56 pounds and, despite dieting, she could not drop the weight.
Scans revealed an ovarian cyst that swelled over 11 months to a whopping 73 pounds – equal to a 10-year-old child – and put her at risk of heart failure.
The pressure from the cyst meant she had problems walking, breathing and eating due to the compression on her organs.
Last year Dr. Erik Hanson Viana, 27, at the Mexico General Hospital, performed pioneering surgery to remove the cyst.
Now, more than six months on, the woman can walk again and lives a normal life.
Viana, from Mexico City, said: “This is the biggest cyst I have operated on, it was so large that it took up 95 percent of the patient’s abdomen.
Viana holds the gigantic cyst after he removed it from the 24-year-old patient. Caters News “It’s really rare to operate on a cyst this big, it measured [a foot and a half] in diameter and the circumference was [around 5 feet].”
“From all the research I’ve found, it’s believed that this is the largest ovarian cyst ever to be removed whole, without draining it first or spilling it.”
“The largest in history weighed 320 pounds back in 1902, and took several days to drain, I can’t even imagine one that large.”
Viana said the patient was overweight, but after starting on a diet she noticed her arms, legs and face were getting slimmer but her stomach was getting bigger.
He said: “When I met her, she could just about walk a couple of steps before getting agitated and feeling like she was struggling to breathe because the cyst was crushing her lungs .”
“If we hadn’t operated it would have gotten to the point where she wouldn’t have been able to walk, would be severely malnourished and unable to eat.”
“It’s hard to say how long she would have lived, but it would have been a really bad quality of life.”
“Two days after surgery she walked out of the hospital.”

“She was standing completely straight. She now walks like a normal person without needing a walking stick or other mobility aids and her abdomen is now flat.”
The patient was referred to Mexico General Hospital as a last resort due to the concerning size of the ovarian cyst and the complicated surgery needed to remove it.
The patient after the cyst was removed. Caters News Viana said: “Since the cyst had become so large, it had started to compress her intestines and was preventing her from eating.”
“She would be full after eating a tiny bit of food and because of the cyst’s size, it was harder for food to pass from the stomach.”
“The cyst was also compressing the two main vessels in the body, which could have led to serious heart problems.”
Due to its size, Viana and Dr. Abel Jalife removed the tumor whole because they feared that draining the cyst could put the patient’s life at risk.
Up to 20 percent of giant ovarian cysts are malignant, meaning that if the cyst was pierced it risked leaking tumorous cells into the patient’s body.
Viana said: “Draining beforehand can be dangerous. If any of the fluid spilled, it risked contaminating the patient’s abdominal wall and spreading tumor cells.”
“But to remove it whole is also difficult because the cyst wall is less than one millimeter thin and needs to be prevented from drying out, otherwise it could easily break too.”
“A big part of what we do is the gratification you feel when you could change a person’s life completely, and knowing they would never forget you, even if they forget to say thank you.”
